z:row.TitlePrimary: Protection of simple series and parallel systems with components of different values
z:row.Publisher: Elsevier Ltd, Oxford, OX5 1GB, United Kingdom
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706-1572, United States
z:row.Abstract: We apply game theory, optimization, and reliability analysis to identify optimal defenses against intentional threats to system reliability. The goals are to identify optimal strategies for allocating resources among possible defensive investments, and to develop qualitative guidelines that reflect those strategies. The novel feature of the approach is the use of reliability analysis together with game theory and optimization to study optimal management of intentional threats to system reliability. Thus, this work extends and adapts the existing body of game-theoretic work on security to systems with series or parallel structures. The results yield insights into the nature of optimal defensive investments that yield the best tradeoff between investment cost and security. In particular, the results illustrate how the optimal allocation of defensive investments depends on the structure of the system, the cost-effectiveness of infrastructure protection investments, and the adversary's goals and constraints. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Parallel systems; Series systems; Defensive investments; Optimal allocation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Implications of the research on expert overconfidence and dependence
z:row.Keyword: Cognitive systems|Reliability|Calibration|Uncertain systems|Random processes|Numerical analysis|Probability distributions|Mathematical techniques
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Department of Industrial Engineering, Ctr. for Hum. Perf./Risk Analysis, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706-1571, United States
z:row.Abstract: In cases where interval estimates are obtained from expert opinion, the literature on expert overconfidence and dependence suggests that caution is in order. In particular, it may be inadvisable in such cases to interpret any areas of overlap among the intervals provided by the various experts as strong evidence that the quantity of interest falls within the region of overlap. The available literature on methods for assessing and compensating for overconfidence and for combining intervals or probability distributions from multiple experts is discussed. An ad hoc method of combining multiple expert opinions, suitable for use in relatively small projects, is also presented. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Expert opinion; Overconfidence; Dependence; Expert aggregation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Deregulation and safety
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: The effect of electricity deregulation on the nuclear power safety is discussed. The deregulation made the costs and benefits of maintenance activities more important. Because of cost minimization, some safety-related maintenance activities might get curtailed. However, the reliability benefits associated with preventive maintenance might take an important place, because of costs of unplanned outages affect the deregulated companies directly.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Nuclear power safety; Midair collisions; Equipment maintenance

z:row.TitlePrimary: Optimal Allocation of Resources for Defense of Simple Series and Parallel Systems from Determined Adversaries
z:row.TitleSecondary: Risk-Based Decisionmaking in Water Resources X: Proceedings of the Tenth Conference, Nov 3-8 2002
z:row.TitleTertiary: Risk-Based Decisionmaking in Water Resources X
z:row.Keyword: Resource allocation|Parallel processing systems|Risk management|Decision making|Game theory|Earthquakes|Computer crime|Probability
z:row.Publisher: American Society of Civil Engineers, Reston, VA 20191-4400, United States
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Barbara, CA, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Industrial Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: Managing the risks posed by an intelligent and adaptable adversary is different from many other types of risk management. Thus, risk management in this context is a problem of game theory rather than decision theory. In other words, the defender wishes to choose the optimal strategy for defending against an optimal attack, and vice versa. In this paper, we apply game theory to help in characterizing optimal defensive strategies against intentional attacks. The results yield useful insights.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Anthrax attacks; Computer hackers

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the state of the art: Risk communication to decision-makers
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper reviews the state of the art on risk communication to decision-makers, with an emphasis on issues involved in communicating technical results. In particular, the paper discusses the treatment of uncertainty, variability, and dependence. It also reviews suggestions from the literature regarding the appropriate format of risk communication messages to decision-makers. Due to the lack of detailed empirical investigations and definitive results about this topic, the paper is not intended to be a comprehensive review, but rather as an exploration of key issues in this area.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Risk communication

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the state of the art: Risk communication to the public
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper reviews the state of the art on risk communication to the public, with an emphasis on summarizing relevant empirical findings. In particular, the paper reviews empirical results regarding the format of risk communication messages, the use of risk comparisons, audience differences, and the use of mental models as an aid in crafting effective risk communication messages. Later sections discuss the issue of credibility and trust in risk communication, and the use of stakeholder participation processes - important areas in which not as much rigorous empirical information is available. Due to the breadth of the topic, the paper is not intended to be a comprehensive review, but rather an overview of the voluminous literature in this area.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Risk communication; Risk perception

z:row.TitlePrimary: Challenges and opportunities of risk-informed decision making for U.S. Department of Energy facilities
z:row.TitleSecondary: 2000 International Conference on Nuclear Science and Technology: Supporting Sustainable Development Worldwide, 12-16 Nov. 2000
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Washington, DC, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In the commercial nuclear power industry, risk-informed decision making has been recognized as having the potential to create a win/win situation for both safety and cost. For example, existing deterministic regulations for component testing frequencies were largely established on an ad hoc basis before probabilistic risk analysis (PRA) techniques were available, and may thus apply the same requirements to components with very different contributions to plant risk. Thus, of several dozen valves that must be tested on a monthly basis, a few may be so risk significant that they merit more frequent testing (e.g., weekly), and many others may contribute so little to risk that they can be safely tested less often (e.g., yearly). Increased testing of the few risk-critical components can significantly decrease risk for little increase in cost, while decreased testing of the many less significant components can substantially reduce cost with only a small increase in risk. Thus, the South Texas Project (STP) expects to save $1 million per year by using risk-informed decision making to optimize maintenance for components that are not subject to regulatory requirements, and another $1.3 million if the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) approves similar changes for components governed by regulation
z:row.User2: risk-informed decision making; South Texas Project; nuclear facilities

z:row.TitlePrimary: Survey of approaches for assessing and managing the risk of extremes
z:row.Keyword: Risk assessment|Risk management|Probability distributions|Mathematical models|Optimization|Management science
z:row.Publisher: Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publ Corp, New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In this paper, we review methods for assessing and managing the risk of extreme events, where 'extreme events' are defined to be rare, severe, and outside the normal range of experience of the system in question. First, we discuss several systematic approaches for identifying possible extreme events. We then discuss some issues related to risk assessment of extreme events, including what type of output is needed (e.g., a single probability vs. a probability distribution), and alternatives to the probabilistic approach. Next, we present a number of probabilistic methods. These include: guidelines for eliciting informative probability distributions from experts; maximum entropy distributions; extreme value theory; other approaches for constructing prior distributions (such as reference or noninformative priors); the use of modeling and decomposition to estimate the probability (or distribution) of interest; and bounding methods. Finally, we briefly discuss several approaches for managing the risk of extreme events, and conclude with recommendations and directions for future research.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Extreme events; Extreme value theory; Judgemental distributions

z:row.TitlePrimary: Extremes, extrapolation, and surprise
z:row.Keyword: Risk assessment|Extrapolation|Probability distributions|Computer simulation|Statistical methods|Mathematical models|Sensitivity analysis
z:row.Publisher: Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publ Corp, New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: As part of the second workshop on 'When and How Can You Specify a Probability Distribution When You Don't Know Much?' held at the University of Virginia on March 12-14, 1997, focuses on the occurrence of unexpected events. First, the use of empirical evidence to characterize rare events and the methods to create or assess probability distribution for such events are detailed. The usefulness of the extreme value theory and the three Gumbel distribution types for pinpointing such events is discussed. Finally, the importance of finding bounds, communicating extreme events to policymakers and the public, and formulating decision standards is highlighted.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Extreme event; Bayes theorem; Tail probabilities

z:row.TitlePrimary: Challenges to the acceptance of probabilistic risk analysis
z:row.Keyword: Risk assessment|Probabilistic logics|Decision making|Behavioral research|Laws and legislation|Errors|Societies and institutions
z:row.Publisher: Blackwell Publishers Inc, New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, University Avenue Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper discusses a number of the key challenges to the acceptance and application of probabilistic risk analysis (PRA). Those challenges include: (a) the extensive reliance on subjective judgement in PRA, requiring the development of guidance for the use of PRA in risk-informed regulation, and possibly the development of 'robust' or 'reference' prior distributions to minimize the reliance on judgement; and (b) the treatment of human performance in PRA, including not only human error per se but also management and organizational factors more broadly. All of these areas are seen as presenting interesting research challenges at the interface between engineering and other disciplines.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Probabilistic risk analysis; Risk informed regulation; Subjective judgement; Robust Bayesian analysis; Human performance; Human error; Corporate culture

z:row.TitlePrimary: Analysis of decomposition for subjective estimation in decision analysis
z:row.PeriodicalAbbrev: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics Part A:Systems and Humans.
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, GA, USA
z:row.Abstract: In decision analysis, it is frequently necessary to obtain reasonably precise estimates of unknown quantities, including both probabilities and utilities. Decomposition is often used for this purpose, under the assumption that it is preferable to direct elicitation. In this context, decomposition involves estimating the conditional means of the quantity of interest for a finite number of conditioning events, and weighting the means by the estimated probabilities of these events. We propose a model for how the precision of estimates obtained using decomposition depends on the choice of conditioning events. A novel feature of this model is that it captures how the choice or conditioning events influences both the conditional means and the conditional variances simultaneously. This makes it possible to characterize not only when decomposition is preferable to direct elicitation, but also when highly informative decompositions are preferred to less informative ones. Intuitive explanations of these results are provided. In addition, when the estimated probabilities of the conditioning events are reasonably precise, our results are consistent with conventional wisdom in decision analysis, and bear strong similarity to results on the construction of strata in stratified sampling.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Conditioning event selection; Subjective probability assessment

z:row.TitlePrimary: Aggregation error in Bayesian analysis of reliability systems
z:row.Publisher: Inst Oper Res Manage Sci, Linthicum, MD, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Perfect aggregation in Bayesian system reliability analysis has been shown to be extremely unlikely. In other words, aggregation error is almost inevitable. Consequently, analysts have to deal with the following dilemma: on one hand, an aggregate analysis (i.e., an analysis at the system level), while relatively inexpensive, may be misleading. On the other hand, a disaggregate analysis (i.e., at the component level) provides more accurate results, but may be costly and impractical. Therefore, simple techniques to estimate the size of aggregation error are necessary to help analysts choose the most appropriate level of detail for an analysis. In this paper, reasonable bounds on the aggregation error are derived for a variety of reliability models. In particular, these bounds will never be more than twice the actual error. Tools to compute these bounds (and in some cases the actual error) are also provided.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Aggregation error; Bayesian analysis; System level analysis; Component level analysis

z:row.TitlePrimary: A Bayesian method for analyzing dependencies in precursor data
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Past Bayesian methods for analyzing accident precursor data have rested on unreasonable simplifying assumptions; in particular, the assumption that successive stages of each accident sequence (e.g. successive system failures) are independent. However, obtaining information on intersystem dependencies is one of the greatest benefits of precursor analysis. With such dependencies, each system may have not one but several conditional failure probabilities; for example, one under normal or test conditions, and another during accident conditions (e.g. after other systems have already failed). These probabilities, while not identical, may be correlated, since the system will contain the same components (with the same inherent reliability levels) regardless of whether other systems have already failed. In this paper, extended natural conjugate distributions are used in a Bayesian method to analyze pairs of correlated probabilities. While motivated by applications to precursor analysis, the method is in fact quite general
z:row.User2: Bayesian method; accident precursor data analysis; intersystem dependencies; conditional failure probabilities; test conditions; accident conditions; extended natural conjugate distributions; correlated probabilities

z:row.TitlePrimary: Performance of precursor-based estimators for rare event frequencies
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Data on accident 'precursors' or 'near misses' can help in obtaining accurate estimators of accident frequencies when actual accident data is sparse. A variety of precursor-based estimators have been proposed in the literature. This paper presents results of a simulation study to assess the statistical performance of several such estimators, to help in determining which are the most suitable for use in practice.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Precursor based estimators; Statistical performance; Single accident sequence; Safety systems

z:row.TitlePrimary: Perfect aggregation for a class of general reliability models with Bayesian updating
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Aggregation is an important tool for handling complex problems, because it can reduce a large number of parameters in the original problem to a smaller number of aggregate parameters. Unfortunately, most aggregated problems yield results different from those of the original problems, a fact that is not widely recognized; in other words, perfect aggregation is usually not achieved. We develop necessary and sufficient conditions for perfect aggregation in Bayesian estimation (i.e., consistency of Bayesian analyses performed at the system and component levels) for a class of frequently used reliability models. The conditions for perfect aggregation are shown to be extremely stringent. Also, some implications of these results are discussed. In particular, because perfect aggregation is very unlikely, analyzing data at the system level when component or subsystem level data are available can be misleading
z:row.User2: perfect aggregation; general reliability models; Bayesian updating; aggregate parameters; aggregated problems; sufficient conditions; Bayesian estimation; Bayesian analyses; frequently used reliability models; system level; subsystem level data

z:row.TitlePrimary: Perfect aggregation in Bayesian estimation for several realistic reliability models
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Previous work by one of the authors has shown that for simple two-component reliability systems aggregation error occurs in Bayesian estimation except under very restrictive conditions. In this paper, necessary and sufficient conditions for perfect aggregation are developed for more complicated reliability systems. The results show that the conditions for perfect aggregation are no less restrictive than those derived previously for simple systems. An example is provided to give the flavor of what will happen for the more general case. In addition, some implications of this work are discussed
z:row.User2: perfect aggregation; Bayesian estimation; realistic reliability models; aggregation error; necessary and sufficient conditions

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ambiguity seeking in multi-attribute decisions: effects of optimism and message framing
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper investigates the influence of message framing and personality variables on preferences over ambiguity in the context of multi-attribute decision scenarios. Undergraduate subjects responded to scenarios in which one of two medical treatments was associated with ambiguous probabilities of treatment effects. Probabilities were either positively or negatively framed. Subjects indicated their degree of preference for one treatment over the other. Subjects' optimism, trait anxiety, health locus of control, need for cognitive structure, and current mood were measured. In two separate studies, subjects preferred ambiguity when probabilities were positively framed, and were neutral toward ambiguity when probabilities were negatively framed. Also, in both studies the preference for ambiguity in positively framed scenarios was greater for more optimistic subjects. The unexpected finding of ambiguity seeking may be associated with the use of different decision strategies in multi-attribute versus single-attribute decisions
z:row.User2: message framing; personality variables; preferences; ambiguity seeking; multiattribute decisions; probability; optimism; trait anxiety; cognitive structure; current mood

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the concept of perfect aggregation in Bayesian estimation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Perfect aggregation is here defined as consistency between the results of aggregate (i.e. system-level) and disaggregate (i.e. component-level) reliability analyses of the same system using Bayesian estimation. This paper identifies necessary and sufficient conditions for perfect aggregation in simple two-component systems, and discusses the implications of these results for more complex systems. Unfortunately, we show that even in systems with only two components, perfect aggregation is achieved only in very rare special cases, which will generally not be obtained in practice. Therefore, tools are needed to estimate the magnitude of aggregation error when perfect aggregation is not achieved.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Perfect aggregation; Bayesian estimation; Reliability analysis; Aggregation error

z:row.TitlePrimary: When uncertainty is irrelevant to expected utility decision making
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1993 (2nd) International Symposium on Uncertainty Modeling and Analysis, 25-28 April 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: [1993] Proceedings Second International Symposium on Uncertainty Modeling and Analysis
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: College Park, MD, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The author discusses the expected value of including uncertainty in decision making, and also normative bases of ambiguity aversion. It is shown that there are broad classes of utility functions for which uncertainty is irrelevant under expected utility theory, and only mean values are significant. Conversely, there are broad classes of utility functions for which preferences over ambiguity are normatively valid. Finally, preferences over ambiguity, even if valid, are not always relevant to decision making; decision makers may have lower expected utility when a probability is ambiguous than when it is certain, but have the same set of optimal decisions in either case
z:row.User2: uncertainty; decision making; normative bases; ambiguity aversion; utility functions; utility theory; optimal decisions

z:row.TitlePrimary: Statistical methods for the use of accident precursor data in estimating the frequency of rare events
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In estimating the frequency of rare events, the number of observed events is usually too small to support the development of accurate estimates by means of the usual statistical estimator, i.e., the number of events divided by the years of experience. Data on accident `precursors' can help in obtaining a reasonably accurate estimator. However, past attempts to use precursor data have been problematic. In the work described here, the authors assess the problems associated with various precursor-based estimators of rare event frequencies, and propose a new estimator that seems suitable for use in practice. However, the results suggest that the competing goals of achieving low noise and low bias are inherently incompatible. Therefore, the authors recommend possible directions for future work to explore this tradeoff in more depth.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Accident precursor data; Rare event frequency; Estimator

z:row.TitlePrimary: New insights gained from accident precursor data
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1992 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 7-12 June 1992
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Boston, MA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors undertook a qualitative review of recent accident precursors. The purposes of this review were (a) to assess the validity of PRA models and results, (b) to identify possible improvements to PRA models, and (c) to identify possible plant improvements
z:row.User2: probabilistic risk assessment; accident precursors

z:row.TitlePrimary: Issues in the estimation of ageing in event frequencies
z:row.TitleSecondary: Use of Probabilistic Safety Assessment for Operational Safety. PSA '91. Proceedings of an International Symposium, 3-7 June 1991
z:row.TitleTertiary: Use of Probabilistic Safety Assessment for Operational Safety. PSA '91. Proceedings of an International Symposium
z:row.Keyword: ageing|fission reactor safety|fission reactor theory and design
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Vienna, Austria
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Most models for detecting ageing related trends in event frequencies are characterized by an initial frequency and a rate of increase in that frequency. This rate of increase will be referred to as the `ageing rate'. In the work described, Bayesian analysis was applied to data on events such as emergency safety function (ESF) actuations, ESF failures, and scrams using a linear ageing model. The results showed that estimates of ageing rates and future event frequencies can be quite sensitive to both the choice of prior distributions and the method of analysis, and that data will often be too sparse to permit a reliable determination of whether ageing is occurring. These observations have significant implications for ageing management efforts
z:row.User2: ageing; event frequencies; initial frequency; Bayesian analysis; emergency safety function; ESF; scrams; management efforts

z:row.TitlePrimary: Is fuzzy set theory more general than probability theory?
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings. First International Symposium on Uncertainty Modeling and Analysis (Cat. No.90TH0334-3), 3-5 Dec. 1990
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings. First International Symposium on Uncertainty Modeling and Analysis (Cat. No.90TH0334-3)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: College Park, MD, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Fuzzy set theory and possibility theory are often described as extensions or generalizations of classical set theory and probability theory, respectively. Thus, for example, fuzzy sets are described as generalizations of the crisp sets used in classical set theory. Similarly, possibility theorists argue that the conventional definitions of fuzzy union and intersection (i.e. the max and min operations) are logical extensions of the corresponding operations in classical set theory. This paper shows that the operations of fuzzy union and intersection as conventionally defined can be viewed as special cases of probabilistic union and intersection. Under this interpretation, the fuzzy complement or negation is a generalization of the corresponding probabilistic operation, but fuzzy union and intersection are not. The relationships between fuzzy and probabilistic union and intersection also suggest a possible analogy to the Venn diagrams used to depict traditional set union and intersection
z:row.User2: fuzzy intersection; fuzzy negation; fuzzy set theory; probability theory; possibility theory; fuzzy union; fuzzy complement

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the state of the art: risk communication to the public
z:row.Keyword: risk communication|risk perception|risk comparisons|mental models|trust|stakeholder participation|CORRECTING MENTAL MODELS|NUCLEAR-ENERGY SOURCES|GLOBAL|CLIMATE-CHANGE|HAZARDOUS PROCESSES|PERCEIVED RISK|PEOPLE KNOW|PERCEPTION|PROBABILITY|EXPRESSIONS|MANAGEMENT|Engineering, Industrial|Operations Research & Management Science
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD OX5 1GB, OXON, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Human Performance & Risk Anal, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Bier, VM, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Human Performance & Risk Anal, 1513 Univ Ave, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: This paper reviews the state of the art on risk communication to the public, with an emphasis on summarizing relevant empirical findings. Ln particular, the paper reviews empirical results regarding the format of risk communication messages, the use of risk comparisons, audience differences, and the use of mental models as an aid in crafting effective risk communication messages. Later sections discuss the issue of credibility and trust in risk communication, and the use of stakeholder participation processes - important areas in which not as much rigorous empirical information is available. Due to the breadth of the topic, the paper is not intended to be a comprehensive review, but rather an overview of the voluminous literature in this area. (C) 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the state of the art: risk communication to decision-makers
z:row.Keyword: risk communication|decision-making|uncertainty|variability|dependence|value of information|Engineering, Industrial|Operations Research & Management Science
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD OX5 1GB, OXON, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Human Performance & Risk Anal, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Bier, VM, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Human Performance & Risk Anal, 1513 Univ Ave, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: This paper reviews the state of the art on risk communication to decision-makers, with an emphasis on issues involved in communicating technical results. In particular, the paper discusses the treatment of uncertainty, variability, and dependence. It also reviews suggestions from the literature regarding the appropriate format of risk communication messages to decision-makers. Due to the lack of detailed empirical investigations and definitive results about this topic, the paper is not intended to be a comprehensive review, but rather as an exploration of key issues in this area. (C) 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Applying Bayesian ideas in simulation
z:row.Keyword: Bayesian statistics|prior distributions|input analysis|output analysis|verification and validation|UNCERTAINTY|RISK|Computer Science, Interdisciplinary Applications|Computer Science, Software Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: AMSTERDAM; PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Georgia Inst Technol, Sch Ind & Syst Engn, Atlanta, GA 30332 USA.; Bier, VM, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, 1513 Univ Ave, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The standard approach to analyzing the results of probabilistic simulation rests on the use of classical statistics. In this paper, we explore the use of Bayesian statistics as an alternative. This makes it possible to incorporate prior information into the analysis of simulation results in a formal and rigorous manner, through the use of prior distributions. The Bayesian approach will typically yield improved analyses, by better taking into account what is actually known and what is not known about the system to be simulated (assuming that the prior distributions themselves adequately represent this knowledge). We briefly review Bayesian methods for readers who are not familiar with this type of analysis and suggest ways in which these methods can be applied to simulation. Specifically, we explore the use of Bayesian statistics for verification and validation of simulation models and for simulation output analysis, in both cases using priors on the performance measures of interest. We then study the use of prior distributions on the input parameters to the simulation, as a way to quantify the effects of input uncertainties on both the mean and the uncertainty of the performance measures of interest, and discuss Bayesian and related methods for choosing input distributions. Finally, we briefly consider the use of a joint prior on both the input parameters and the resulting performance measures. Bayesian methods are particularly appropriate for use in practice when simulations are costly, or when input uncertainties are large. Our work provides guidance on the use of Bayesian methods for simulation analysis. We hope that it will stimulate readers to learn more about this important subject, and also encourage further research in this area. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Challenges to the acceptance of probabilistic risk analysis
z:row.Keyword: probabilistic risk analysis|subjective judgment|risk-informed regulation|robust Bayesian analysis|human performance|human error|management and organizational factors|corporate culture|POWER|Mathematics, Interdisciplinary Applications|Social Sciences, Mathematical Methods
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 233 SPRING ST, NEW YORK, NY 10013 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Bier, VM, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, 1513 Univ Ave, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: This paper discusses a number of the key challenges to the acceptance and application of probabilistic risk analysis (PRA). Those challenges include: (a) the extensive reliance on subjective judgment in PRA, requiring the development of guidance for the use of PRA in risk-informed regulation, and possibly the development of "robust" or "reference" prior distributions to minimize the reliance on judgment; and (b) the treatment of human performance in PRA, including not only human error per se but also management and organizational factors more broadly. All of these areas are seen as presenting interesting research challenges at the interface between engineering and other disciplines.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Defaults and incentives in risk-informed regulation
z:row.Keyword: defaults|risk-informed regulation|Nuclear Regulatory Commission|Environmental Protection Agency|risk analysis|PERILS|Environmental Sciences
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BOCA RATON; 2000 CORPORATE BLVD NW, JOURNALS CUSTOMER SERVICE, BOCA RATON, FL 33431 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Korea Atom Energy Res Inst, Yusung Ku, Taejon 305600, South Korea.; Bier, VM, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, 1513 Univ Ave, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Both performing and validating a detailed risk analysis of a complex system are costly and time-consuming undertakings. With the increased use of probabilistic risk analysis (PRA) in regulatory decision making, both regulated parties and regulators have generally favored the use of defaults, because they can greatly facilitate the process of performing a PRA in the first place, as well as the process of reviewing and verifying the PRA. The use of defaults may also ensure more uniform standards of PRA quality. :However, regulatory agencies differ in their approaches to the use of default values, and the implications of these differences are not yet well understood. Moreover, large heterogeneity among licensees makes it difficult to set suitable defaults. This paper focuses on the effect of default values on estimates of risk. In particular, we explore the effects of different levels of conservatism in setting defaults, and their implications for the crafting of regulatory incentives. The results can help decision makers evaluate the levels of safety likely to result from their regulatory policies.

z:row.TitlePrimary: A survey of approaches for assessing and managing the risk of extremes
z:row.Keyword: extreme events|risk assessment|risk management|extreme value theory|judgmental distributions|MANAGEMENT|PROBABILITY|VARIABILITY|FRAMEWORK|EVENTS|Mathematics, Interdisciplinary Applications|Social Sciences, Mathematical Methods
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 233 SPRING ST, NEW YORK, NY 10013 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Virginia, Ctr Risk Management Engn Syst, Charlottesville, VA 22903 USA. NYU, Robert F Wagner Grad Sch Publ Serv, New York, NY 10003 USA.; Bier, VM, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, 1513 Un(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: In this paper, we review methods for assessing and managing the risk of extreme events, where "extreme events" are defined to be rare, severe, and outside the normal range of experience of the system in question. First, we discuss several systematic approaches for identifying possible extreme events. We then discuss some issues related to risk assessment of extreme events, including what type of output is needed (e.g., a single probability vs, a probability distribution), and alternatives to the probabilistic approach. Next, we present a number of probabilistic methods. These include : guidelines for eliciting informative probability distributions from experts; maximum entropy distributions; extreme value theory; other approaches for constructing prior distributions (such as reference or noninformative priors); the use of modeling and decomposition to estimate the probability (or distribution) of interest; and bounding methods. Finally, we briefly discuss several approaches for managing the risk of extreme events, and conclude with recommendations and directions for future research.

z:row.TitlePrimary: A natural conjugate prior for the nonhomogeneous Poisson process with an exponential intensity function
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 270 MADISON AVE, NEW YORK, NY 10016 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Ming Chuan Univ, Dept Informat Management, Taipei 11120, Taiwan. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: This article presents a natural conjugate prior for the nonhomogeneous Poisson process (NHPP) with an exponential intensity function, for modeling the failure rate of repairable systems. The behavior of the conjugate prior distribution with respect to its parameters is studied, and the use of this prior in Bayesian estimation is compared to two other estimation approaches (the use of independent prior distributions, and the bivariate normal distribution). The use of the conjugate prior proposed here facilitates Bayesian statistical analysis of aging. In particular, the proposed prior allows us to explicitly account for dependence between the initial failure rate and the aging rate. This is a significant improvement over the assumptions made in most prior work (either the assumption that the aging rate is known, or the assumption that the initial failure rate and the aging rate are independent). Monte Carlo simulation shows that Bayesian estimation using the proposed prior generally performs at least as well as Bayesian estimation using independent priors for the initial failure rate and the aging rate, except in the case where the prior distribution underestimates both the initial failure rate and the aging rate.

z:row.TitlePrimary: An application of copulas to accident precursor analysis
z:row.Keyword: copulas|accident precursors|risk analysis|dependencies|Bayesian analysis|BIVARIATE DISTRIBUTIONS|EXPERT OPINIONS|INFORMATION|FREQUENCY|RISK|Management|Operations Research & Management Science
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LINTHICUM HTS; 901 ELKRIDGE LANDING RD, STE 400, LINTHICUM HTS, MD 21090-2909 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Korea Elect Power Res Inst, Syst & Commun Res Lab, Taejon, South Korea. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Yi, W, Korea Elect Power Res Inst, Syst & Commun Res Lab, Taejon, South Korea.
z:row.Abstract: Data on accident precursors can help in estimating accident frequencies, since they provide a rich source of information on intersystem dependencies. However, Bayesian analysis of accident precursors requires the ability to construct joint prior distributions reflecting such dependencies. For example, the failure probabilities of a particular safety system under normal and accident conditions, respectively, will generally not be identical (because of the effects of the accident), but will almost certainly be correlated (since both failure probabilities reflect the performance of the same components, with the same inherent levels of reliability). In this paper, we explore the use of copulas (a method of representing joint distribution functions with particular marginals) to construct the needed prior distributions, and then use these distributions in a Bayesian analysis of hypothetical precursor data. This demonstrates the usefulness of copulas in practice. The same approach can also be used in a wide variety of other contexts where joint distributions with particular marginals are desired.

z:row.TitlePrimary: An analysis of decomposition for subjective estimation in decision analysis
z:row.Keyword: conditioning event selection|hedging|informative decompositions|stratification|subjective probability assessment|PROBABILITY|JUDGMENTS|UTILITY|Computer Science, Cybernetics|Computer Science, Theory & Methods
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Ieee Transactions on Systems Man and Cybernetics Part A-Systems and Humans
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Georgia Inst Technol, Sch Ind & Syst Engn, Atlanta, GA 30332 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Andradottir, S, Georgia Inst Technol, Sch Ind & Syst Engn, Atlanta, GA 30332 USA.; sa@isye.gatech.edu bier@ie.engr.wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: In decision analysis, it is frequently necessary to obtain reasonably precise estimates of unknown quantities, including both probabilities and utilities. Decomposition is often used for this purpose, under the assumption that it is preferable to direct elicitation. In this contest, decomposition involves estimating the conditional means of the quantity of interest for a finite number of conditioning events, and weighting the means by the estimated probabilities of these events. We propose a model for how the precision of estimates obtained using decomposition depends on the choice of conditioning events. A novel feature of this model is that it captures how the choice of conditioning events influences both the conditional means and the conditional variances simultaneously, This makes it possible to characterize not only when decomposition is preferable to direct elicitation, but also when highly informative decompositions are preferred to less informative ones. Intuitive explanations of these results are provided. In addition, when the estimated probabilities of the conditioning events are reasonably precise, our results are consistent with conventional wisdom in decision analysis, and bear strong similarity to results on the construction of strata in stratified sampling.

z:row.TitlePrimary: A natural conjugate prior for the non-homogeneous Poisson process with a power law intensity function
z:row.Keyword: repairable system|Bayesian estimation|aging|Weibull failure model|Statistics & Probability
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 270 MADISON AVE, NEW YORK, NY 10016 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Ming Chuan Univ, Dept Informat Management, Taipei, Taiwan. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Ind Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: This paper develops a natural conjugate prior for the non-homogeneous Poisson process (NHPP) with a power law intensity function. This prior allows for dependence between the scale factor and the aging rate of the NHPP. The proposed prior has relatively simple closed-form expressions for its moments, facilitating the assessment of prior parameters. The use of this prior in Bayesian estimation is compared to other estimation approaches using Monte Carlo simulation. The results show that Bayesian estimation using the proposed prior generally performs at least as well as either maximum likelihood estimation or Bayesian estimation using independent priors.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Choosing the number of conditioning events in judgemental forecasting
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX, ENGLAND PO19 1UD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,MADISON,WI.; Andradottir, S, GEORGIA INST TECHNOL,SCH IND & SYST ENGN,ATLANTA,GA 30332.
z:row.Abstract: One method for judgemental forecasting involves the use of decomposition; i.e. estimating the conditional means of an unknown quantity of interest for a finite number of conditioning events, and weighting these estimated conditional means by the estimated marginal probabilities of the corresponding conditioning events. In this paper we investigate how the level of decomposition (i.e. the number of conditioning events) affects the precision of the resulting forecast. Previous analyses assume that key parameters (the informativeness of the decomposition, and the precision of estimation for the conditional means and the marginal probabilities) remain constant as the number of conditioning events increases. However, this assumption is unreasonable, and for some parameters mathematically impossible; the values of these parameters are likely to change significantly even for small numbers of conditioning events. Therefore, we introduce models for how these key parameters may depend on the level of decomposition. We then investigate the implications of these models for the precision of the resulting forecast. In particular, we identify cases in which decomposition is never desirable, always desirable, or desirable only near the optimal number of conditioning events. This second case was not observed previously. We focus throughout on the situation likely to be of greatest interest in practice; namely, the behaviour of decomposition for relatively small numbers of conditioning events. z:row.TitlePrimary: Aggregation error in Bayesian analysis of reliability systems
z:row.Keyword: Bayesian estimation|perfect aggregation|aggregation error|Management|Operations Research & Management Science
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LINTHICUM HTS; 901 ELKRIDGE LANDING RD, STE 400, LINTHICUM HTS, MD 21090-2909
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Azaiez, MN, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,1513 UNIV AVE,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Perfect aggregation in Bayesian system reliability analysis has been shown to be extremely unlikely. In other words, aggregation error is almost inevitable. Consequently, analysts have to deal with the following dilemma: on one hand, an aggregate analysis (i.e., an analysis at the system level), while relatively inexpensive, may be misleading. On the other hand, a disaggregate analysis (i.e., at the component level) provides more accurate results, but may be costly and impractical. Therefore, simple techniques to estimate the size of aggregation error are necessary to help analysts choose the most appropriate level of detail for an analysis. In this paper, reasonable bounds on the aggregation error are derived for a variety of reliability models. Ln particular, these bounds will never be more than twice the actual error. Tools to compute these bounds (and in some cases the actual error) are also provided.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Uncertainty about probability: A reconciliation with the subjectivist viewpoint
z:row.Keyword: RISK ASSESSMENT|Computer Science, Cybernetics|Computer Science, Theory & Methods
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Ieee Transactions on Systems Man and Cybernetics Part A-Systems and Humans
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,MADISON,WI 53706.; Mosleh, A, UNIV MARYLAND,DEPT MAT & NUCL ENGN,COLLEGE PK,MD 20742.
z:row.Abstract: The use of probability distributions to represent uncertainty about probabilities (rather than events) has long been a subject of controversy among theorists. Many well-known theorists, such as de Finetti, have concluded that it is inherently meaningless to be uncertain about a probability, because this appears to violate the subjectivists' assumption that individuals can develop unique and precise probability judgments. Others have found the concept of uncertainty about probability to be both intuitively appealing and potentially useful. This paper presents a resolution of this question, indicating that at least one type of uncertainty about probabilities (that arising from uncertainty about the underlying events on which those probabilities are conditioned) is consistent with the subjective theory of probability. Another type of uncertainty (namely, that arising from cognitive imprecision) appears not to be consistent with the axioms of subjective probability as they are currently formulated. Distinguishing between these two sources of uncertainty is an important step in resolving the persistent theoretical controversy over uncertainty about probability. We also show that uncertainty about probability will be potentially relevant to decision making whenever the expected value of the relevant performance measure is nonlinear in the probability in question.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Perfect aggregation for a class of general reliability models with Bayesian updating
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 655 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, NY 10010
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Azaiez, MN, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,1513 UNIV AVE,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Aggregation is an important tool for handling complex problems, because it can reduce a large number of parameters in the original problem to a smaller number of aggregate parameters. Unfortunately, most aggregated problems yield results different from those of the original problems, a fact that is not widely recognized; in other words, perfect aggregation is usually not achieved. In this paper, we develop necessary and sufficient conditions for perfect aggregation in Bayesian estimation (i.e., consistency of Bayesian analyses performed at the system and component levels) for a class of frequently used reliability models. The conditions for perfect aggregation are shown to be extremely stringent. Also, some implications of these results are discussed. In particular, because perfect aggregation is very unlikely, analyzing data at the system level when component- or subsystem-level data are available can be misleading.

z:row.TitlePrimary: The performance of precursor-based estimators for rare event frequencies
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, OXON, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Bier, VM, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,1513 UNIV AVE,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Data on accident 'precursors' or 'near misses' can help in obtaining accurate estimators of accident frequencies when actual accident data is sparse. A variety of precursor-based estimators have been proposed in the literature. This paper presents results of a simulation study to assess the statistical performance of several such estimators, to help in determining which are the most suitable for use in practice.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: ABRAMSON LR, 1994, UNPUB 2 PSAM APOSTOLAKIS GE, 1979, NUCL SCI ENG, V70, P133 BARLOW RE, 1975, STATISTICAL THEORY R BIER VM, 1993, RELIAB ENG SYST SAFE, V41, P267 BIER VM, 1995, INT J FORECASTING, V11, P25 COOKE R, 1990, RELIAB ENG SYST SAFE, V27, P117 COTTRELL WB, 1984, NUREGCR3591 USNRC FULLWOOD RR, 1988, PROBABILISTIC RISK A MINARICK JW, 1982, NUREGCR2497 USNRC MINARICK JW, 1990, RELIAB ENG SYST SAFE, V27, P23 PHUNG DL, 1985, NUREGCR2497; NR: 11; TC: 1; J9: RELIAB ENG SYST SAFETY; PG: 11; GA: TP260; UT: ISI:A1995TP26000003

z:row.TitlePrimary: A Bayesian Method for Analyzing Dependencies in Precursor Data
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: AMSTERDAM; PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: BIER, VM, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,1513 UNIV AVE,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Past Bayesian methods for analyzing accident precursor data have rested on unreasonable simplifying assumptions; in particular, the assumption that successive stages of each accident sequence (e.g. successive system failures) are independent. However, obtaining information on intersystem dependencies is one of the greatest benefits of precursor analysis. With such dependencies, each system may have not one but several conditional failure probabilities; for example, one under normal or test conditions, and another during accident conditions (e.g. after other systems have already failed). These probabilities, while not identical, may be correlated, since the system will contain the same components (with the same inherent reliability levels) regardless of whether other systems have already failed. In this paper, extended natural conjugate distributions are used in a Bayesian method to analyze pairs of correlated probabilities. While motivated by applications to precursor analysis, the method is in fact quite general.

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the Concept of Perfect Aggregation in Bayesian-Estimation
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, OXON, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: BIER, VM, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,1513 UNIV AVE,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Perfect aggregation is here defined as consistency between the results of aggregate (i.e. system-level) and disaggregate (i.e. component-level) reliability analyses of the same system using Bayesian estimation. This paper identifies necessary and sufficient conditions for perfect aggregation in simple two-component systems, and discusses the implications of these results for more complex systems. Unfortunately, we show that even in systems with only two components, perfect aggregation is achieved only in very rare special cases, which will generally not be obtained in practice. Therefore, tools are needed to estimate the magnitude of aggregation error when perfect aggregation is not achieved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Perfect Aggregation in Bayesian-Estimation for several Realistic Reliability Models
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 655 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, NY 10010
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AZAIEZ, MN, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,1513 UNIV AVE,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Previous work by one of the authors [1] has shown that for simple two-component reliability systems aggregation error occurs in Bayesian estimation except under very restrictive conditions. In this paper, necessary and sufficient conditions for perfect aggregation are developed for more complicated reliability systems. The results show that the conditions for perfect aggregation are no less restrictive than those derived previously for simple systems. An example is provided to give the flavor of what will happen for the more general case. In addition, some implications of this work are discussed.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ambiguity Seeking in Multiattribute Decisions - Effects of Optimism and Message Framing
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX, ENGLAND PO19 1UD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT PSYCHOL,MADISON,WI 53706.; BIER, VM, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,1513 UNIV AVE,ROOM 451,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: This paper investigates the influence of message framing and personality variables on preferences over ambiguity in the context of multi-attribute decision scenarios. Undergraduate subjects responded to scenarios in which one of two medical treatments was associated with ambiguous probabilities of treatment effects. Probabilities were either positively or negatively framed. Subjects indicated their degree of preference for one treatment over the other. Subjects' optimism, trait anxiety, health locus of control, need for cognitive structure, and current mood were measured. In two separate studies, subjects preferred ambiguity when probabilities were positively framed, and were neutral toward ambiguity when probabilities were negatively framed. Also, in both studies the preference for ambiguity in positively framed scenarios was greater for more optimistic subjects. The unexpected finding of ambiguity seeking may be associated with the use of different decision strategies in multi-attribute versus single-attribute decisions.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Statistical-Methods for the use of Accident Precursor Data in Estimating the Frequency of Rare Events
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, OXON, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: BIER, VM, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,1513 UNIV AVE,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: In estimating the frequency of rare events, the number of observed events is usually too small to support the development of accurate estimates by means of the usual statistical estimator, i.e. the number of events divided by the years of experience. Data on accident 'precursors' can help in obtaining a reasonably accurate estimator. However, past attempts to use precursor data have been problematic. In the work described here, the authors assess the problems associated with various precursor-based estimators of rare event frequencies, and propose a new estimator that seems suitable for use in practice. However, the results suggest that the competing goals of achieving low noise and low bias are inherently incompatible. Therefore, the authors recommend possible directions for future work to explore this tradeoff in more depth.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Risk, Statistical-Inference, and the Law of Evidence - the use of Epidemiologic Data in Toxic Tort Cases
z:row.Keyword: TOXIC TORTS|EPIDEMIOLOGY|BENEDECTIN|BIRTH DEFECTS|ASSIGNED SHARES|CAUSATION|LITIGATION|COMPENSATION|DISEASE|Mathematics, Interdisciplinary Applications|Social Sciences, Mathematical Methods
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 233 SPRING ST, NEW YORK, NY 10013
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: GEORGETOWN UNIV,SCH MED,DEPT RADIAT MED,WASHINGTON,DC. UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,MADISON,WI 53706.; BRANNIGAN, VM, UNIV MARYLAND,DEPT FIRE PROTECT ENGN,COLL PK,MD 20742.
z:row.Abstract: Toxic torts are product liability cases dealing with alleged injuries due to chemical or biological hazards such as radiation, thalidomide, or Agent Orange. Toxic tort cases typically rely more heavily than other product liability cases on indirect or statistical proof of injury. There have been numerous theoretical analyses of statistical proof of injury in toxic tort cases. However, there have been only a handful of actual legal decisions regarding the use of such statistical evidence, and most of those decisions have been inconclusive. Recently, a major case from the Fifth Circuit, involving allegations that Benedectin (a morning sickness drug) caused birth defects, was decided entirely on the basis of statistical inference. This paper examines both the conceptual basis of that decision, and also the relationships among statistical inference, scientific evidence, and the rules of product liability in general.

z:row.TitlePrimary: On Decomposition and Aggregation Error in Estimation - some Basic Principles and Examples
z:row.Keyword: DECOMPOSITION|AGGREGATION|ESTIMATION|RISK ASSESSMENT|PROBABILITY-DISTRIBUTIONS|ECOLOGICAL MODELS|ECOSYSTEMS|JUDGMENTS|FORECASTS|Mathematics, Interdisciplinary Applications|Social Sciences, Mathematical Methods
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 233 SPRING ST, NEW YORK, NY 10013
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT IND ENGN,MADISON,WI 53706.; MOSLEH, A, UNIV MARYLAND,DEPT MAT & NUCL ENGN,COLLEGE PK,MD 20742.
z:row.Abstract: A common strategy in estimation is to decompose the quantity being estimated into several factors, estimate a value for each factor, and then reaggregate these values to obtain an overall estimate. Until now, the extent of decomposition to use has been considered largely a matter of judgment. However, both the extent of decomposition and the manner in which the results are reaggregated can have a significant effect on the resulting estimate. This paper discusses factors affecting the optimum level of decomposition, and presents examples showing that the use of nonoptimal decomposition strategies can lead to significant inaccuracies.
